defs.name: DisplayConsole
defs.docs:
A display console, used internally to provide console render support.
 Public in case you want to play with it, or access it directly.

attributes.value: / A display console, used internally to provide console render support.
/ Public in case you want to play with it, or access it directly.
allow(missing_copy_implementations)
allow(non_camel_case_types)
allow(dead_code)

defs.docs: Registers a new console terminal for output, and returns its handle number.

attributes.value: / Registers a new console terminal for output, and returns its handle number.

defs.name: register_console_no_bg
defs.value: pub fn register_console_no_bg(&mut Self, Box<dyn Console>, usize) -> usize
defs.docs:
Registers a new console terminal for output, and returns its handle number. This variant requests
 that the new console not render background colors, so it can be layered on top of other consoles.

/ that the new console not render background colors, so it can be layered on top of other consoles.

defs.name: render_xp_sprite
defs.value: pub fn render_xp_sprite(&mut Self, &super::rex::XpFile, i32, i32)
defs.docs:
Render a REX Paint (https://www.gridsagegames.com/rexpaint/) file as a sprite.
 The sprite will be offset by offset_x and offset_y.
 Transparent cells will not be rendered.

attributes.value: / Render a REX Paint (https://www.gridsagegames.com/rexpaint/) file as a sprite.
/ The sprite will be offset by offset_x and offset_y.
/ Transparent cells will not be rendered.

defs.name: to_xp_file
defs.value: pub fn to_xp_file(&Self, usize, usize) -> XpFile
defs.docs:
Saves the entire console stack to a REX Paint XP file. If your consoles are of
 varying sizes, the file format supports it - but REX doesn't. So you may want to
 avoid that. You can also get individual layers with `to_xp_layer`.

attributes.value: / Saves the entire console stack to a REX Paint XP file. If your consoles are of
/ varying sizes, the file format supports it - but REX doesn't. So you may want to
/ avoid that. You can also get individual layers with `to_xp_layer`.

defs.name: printer
defs.value:
pub fn printer<S, X, Y>(&mut Self, X, Y, S, TextAlign, Option<RGBA>) where
S: ToString, X: TryInto<i32>, Y: TryInto<i32>
defs.docs:
Print a colorized string with the color encoding defined inline.
 For example: printer(1, 1, "#[blue]This blue text contains a #[pink]pink#[] word")
 You can get the same effect with a TextBlock, but this can be easier.
 Thanks to doryen_rs for the idea.

attributes.value: / Print a colorized string with the color encoding defined inline.
/ For example: printer(1, 1, "#[blue]This blue text contains a #[pink]pink#[] word")
/ You can get the same effect with a TextBlock, but this can be easier.
/ Thanks to doryen_rs for the idea.

Clears the global command buffer. This is called internally by BTerm at the end of each
 frame. You really shouldn't need to call this yourself.

defs.name: printer
defs.value: pub fn printer(&mut Self, i32, i32, &str, TextAlign, Option<RGBA>)
defs.docs:
Print a colorized string with the color encoding defined inline.
 For example: printer(1, 1, "#[blue]This blue text contains a #[pink]pink#[] word")
 You can get the same effect with a TextBlock, but this can be easier.
 Thanks to doryen_rs for the idea.

attributes.value: / Print a colorized string with the color encoding defined inline.
/ For example: printer(1, 1, "#[blue]This blue text contains a #[pink]pink#[] word")
/ You can get the same effect with a TextBlock, but this can be easier.
/ Thanks to doryen_rs for the idea.

 The center of the scale is at character position (center_x, center_y).

defs.name: BTermBuilder
defs.docs:
Provides a builder mechanism for initializing BTerm. You can chain builders together,
 and and with a call to `.build()`. This allows you to provide settings if you want to,
 or just use a simple initializer if you are in a hurry.

/ and and with a call to `.build()`. This allows you to provide settings if you want to,
/ or just use a simple initializer if you are in a hurry.

defs.name: with_dimensions

attributes.value: / Adds width/height dimensions to the BTerm builder.

defs.name: with_tile_dimensions
defs.value: pub fn with_tile_dimensions<T>(Self, T, T) -> Self where T: TryInto<u32>
defs.docs:
Overrides the default assumption for tile sizes. Needed for a raw initialization.
 If you have lots of fonts, the library will pick one (generally the first) to try
 and determine what dimensions you want to use when figuring out your window size.
 This method is used to override that assumption.
 It's a great idea to use this when using multiple layers and fonts.

attributes.value: / Overrides the default assumption for tile sizes. Needed for a raw initialization.
/ If you have lots of fonts, the library will pick one (generally the first) to try
/ and determine what dimensions you want to use when figuring out your window size.
/ This method is used to override that assumption.
/ It's a great idea to use this when using multiple layers and fonts.

Call this to enable the event queue. Otherwise, events will not be tracked/stored outside of the
 HAL setup (to avoid continually filling a buffer that isn't being used).

 `CP437_WINGDINGS.decode(...)` in the `codepage_437` crate!)
